main event: A big ball of blue flame, seemingly about the size of a full moon, was observed in the sky and appeared to dissolve into a thousand sparkles before falling near Moose Factory, Canada on 11th March 1948. The explosion from this incident lit up the entire area brighter than daylight.
interesting points: The object was described as a ball of blue flame, approximately the size of a full moon, which disintegrated as it fell, creating a bright and visually striking event.
No noise was heard during the observation, which adds to the mysterious nature of the sighting.
This incident was observed by a surveyor from the Hudson's Bay Company and tied in with earlier reports from another location, adding credibility to the event.
The object's descent and the subsequent streak of orange light were reported, providing additional details about the behavior and characteristics of the observed object.
The incident was noted to have similarities with earlier reports from a different location, indicating a potential pattern or connection to other sightings.
witnesses: Surveyor from the Hudson's Bay Company
